bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 112 (Tuesday, June 27, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. NORTON:H.R. 4386.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:clause 18 of section 8 of article I of the ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:This bill would would require certain federal judicialofficials who serve the District of Columbia to live withinits boundaries.[Page H3152]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.
Sponsor introductory remarks on measure. (CR E621)

summary.text:
District of Columbia Federal Judicial Officials Residency Equality Act of 2023

This bill requires U.S. district and circuit court judges, U.S. district court clerks, U.S. attorneys, and U.S. marshals who are appointed to serve in the District of Columbia to be residents of the District of Columbia.

bill.title: District of Columbia Federal Judicial Officials Residency Equality Act of 2023

item.title: District of Columbia Federal Judicial Officials Residency Equality Act of 2023
District of Columbia Federal Judicial Officials Residency Equality Act of 2023
To amend title 28, United States Code, to change the residency requirements for certain officials serving in the District of Columbia, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
